awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Ionic Modulation of COVID Through Ceramic Surfaces for Deactivation
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The goal of this research project is to actively capture and decontaminate surfaces from the COVID-19 virus. This project studies atomically tailored ceramic surface coatings by examining ionic exchange, dielectric properties, and physical texturing. Surface activated ceramic particles are interesting due to their biocompatible nature and effective antigerm activity. The size, shape, and morphology of the particles also impact antigerm responses. The possible mechanisms for antiviral activity include both atomic-scale physical and chemical interactions with the virus' body including spike, coating, and capsid. Chemical interactions include photo-activation of the particles, the formation of reactive oxygen species, and metal ion release, while physical interactions include membrane disruption and mechanical damage to the virus. This research applies advanced indirect and direct techniques to study the interaction of the ceramic with the virus at multiple length scales. This project is especially timely for the protection of multiple surfaces, since the US will reopen in the coming months. The project involves teamwork among scientists, engineers, educators, and industry experts. Training the next generation of the workforce with the ability to grasp the philosophy of convergence is another key outcome of this project.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Coronavirus particles have spike proteins (S-proteins) that are responsible for the attachment to the host cells. Specifically, in humans, the SARS and SARS-CoV-2 species have been shown to interact with the host cell receptor protein ACE2 (a zinc metalloprotein). This virus-cell binding is controlled by the polar interaction between the protein molecules. This research project focuses on using polar ceramic-based structures for the capture and deactivation of the coronavirus. Ionic ceramic solids show intrinsic polarity due to the unique arrangement of atoms across different crystalline facets. For example, the alternate basal planes along [0001] direction contain two separate atoms, which lead to intrinsic polarity. The central hypothesis of this research is that ionic surface defects and the polarity on the surface of ceramic particles benefit the effective capture of coronavirus particles and their subsequent deactivation through ionic modulation. Characterization techniques such as atomic force microscopy (AFM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) are being used for the analysis of physical defects. The effect of ionicity on capture and deactivation is being tested via indirect and direct methods. The indirect testing protocol includes inoculation of the surfaces with virus particles and then measuring the number of infectious virus particles. Successful findings are being applied to hard and porous surfaces for aerospace, automotive, retail, and other critical industry sectors.

This grant is being awarded using funds made available by the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act supplement allocated to MPS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project hypothesized that ceramic particles with unique particle shapes, such as ZnO tetrapods, will interact with the viral envelope to physically and chemically damage it, leading to the inactivation of the virus due to their inherent ionic character (Figure-1). The research tested the effect of ZnO tetrapods and their mixtures with other complex ceramics chemistries on the resulting antiviral properties tested per ISO 21702 protocols. Various mixing and coating strategies were explored to ensure that the unique tetrapod shape of the ZnO ceramic particles was preserved on the surface. The results indicate their promise to be used as antiviral surfaces against a broader range of virus strains (not limited to COVID-19 virus only) under specific material compositions and conditions. Salient outcomes for intellectual merit and broader impacts are summarized below:

Intellectual merit:

The researchers learned the intricacies of antiviral testing through first-hand experience as they developed protocols for preparing ceramic-based samples for testing according to the ISO standard using a certified third-party biological testing facility. Antiviral properties for ZnO tetrapod geometry and ZnO tetrapods mixed with complex ceramic chemistries were successfully demonstrated using two strains of viruses (feline calicivirus and human coronavirus OC43). This calls for further detailed investigation to study the role of structure-property-processing in the antiviral response of ceramic mixtures. 

Additionally, this research studied the impact of applying an electric field (to test ionicity) on the stability of a lipid bilayer (simulating the viral envelope). The study partially indicated the rupture of the lipid bilayer, the key to deactivating the virus. Detailed research to optimize the bilayer protocols and electric field application is required to generate robust scientific data for future fundamental research.

Broader impacts:

This research presented multiple learning opportunities for the postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, toward hands-on experimental work and project planning and management. Furthermore, the results indicate the applicability of ZnO tetrapod ceramic-based materials not only for terrestrial applications toward future pandemics but also for broader applicability toward novel and remote locations. As a part of educational impact, this project guided student teams on related work on the development of smart masks as well as digital plugins for ‘protecting against misinformation’ and ‘data-backed surface cleaning recommendations’ during the summer of 2020 (the peak of COVID-19 pandemic).
